surfgeopy.quadrature_points.quadrule_on_flat(deg)[source]ÔÉÅ

Quadrature rule

Parameters:

deg (int) ‚Äì Algebraic degree of precision of the rule.

Returns:

  • weights_ps (ndarray) ‚Äì n-by-1 array of single or double, weights of quadrature points.

  • quad_ps (ndarray) ‚Äì n-by-3 array of single or double, natural coordinates of quadrature points.

surfgeopy.quadrature_points.quadrule_on_simplex(deg)[source]ÔÉÅ
Parameters:

  • deg (Algebraic degree of precision of the rule.) ‚Äì Algebraic degree of precision of the rule.

  • 0] (CUBATURE RULE ON THE SIMPLEX [0 0; 0 1; 1) ‚Äì

  • Legend ‚Äì

  • #DEG (algebraic degree of precision.) ‚Äì

  • #CARD (cardinality of the pointset.) ‚Äì

  • #W- (negative weights.) ‚Äì

  • #PT.O (points outside the simplex [0 0; 1 0; 0 1].) ‚Äì

  • #M.E. (maximum moment error in inf norm.) ‚Äì

  • points (Statistics of quadrature) ‚Äì

  • M.E. (# | DEG | CARD | W- | PT.O|) ‚Äì

  • #------------------------------------ ‚Äì

  • 1.92e-16 (# | 1 | 1 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 1.18e-16 (# | 2 | 3 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 2.15e-16 (# | 3 | 4 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 1.39e-16 (# | 4 | 6 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 1.60e-16 (# | 5 | 7 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 1.08e-15 (# | 6 | 11 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 5.07e-16 (# | 7 | 12 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 8.05e-16 (# | 8 | 16 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 3.26e-16 (# | 9 | 19 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 7.22e-16 (# | 10 | 24 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 3.64e-15 (# | 11 | 27 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 1.61e-15 (# | 12 | 32 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 3.05e-16 (# | 13 | 36 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 4.37e-16 (# | 14 | 42 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 5.00e-16 (# | 15 | 46 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 5.67e-16 (# | 16 | 52 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 5.83e-16 (# | 17 | 57 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 6.11e-16 (# | 18 | 66 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 4.16e-16 (# | 19 | 70 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 4.89e-16 (# | 20 | 78 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 4.64e-16 (# | 21 | 85 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 7.56e-16 (# | 22 | 93 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 6.66e-16 (# | 23 | 100 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 7.81e-16 (# | 24 | 109 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 5.41e-16 (# | 25 | 117 | 0 | 0 |) ‚Äì

  • 0]. (CUBATURE RULE ON THE SIMPLEX [0 0; 0 1; 1) ‚Äì

  • quad_ps (N-by-2 array (single or double),) ‚Äì natural coordinates of quadrature points

surfgeopy.quadrature_points_gl.gauss_legendre_square(deg)[source]ÔÉÅ

Gauss-Legendre cubature rule on the square [-1, 1]^2.

Parameters:

deg (int) ‚Äì Algebraic degree of precision of the rule.

Returns:

  • weights_ps (ndarray) ‚Äì n-by-1 array of single or double, weights of quadrature points.

  • quad_ps (ndarray) ‚Äì n-by-2 array of single or double, natural coordinates of quadrature points.

surfgeopy.quadrature_points_gl.q_gauss_legendre(n, Domain=array([- 1, 1]))[source]ÔÉÅ

Generate quadrature weights and nodes for Gauss-Legendre quadrature rule.

An n-point Gauss-Legendre quadrature rule is of degree 2n-1; that is, it integrates all polynomials up to degree 2n-1 exactly.

Parameters:

  • n (int) ‚Äì Number of sample points and weights. It must be >= 1.

  • Domain (ndarray, optional) ‚Äì Refers to the domain of integration [a, b]. The default domain is the bi-unit interval [-1, 1].

Returns:

  • x (ndarray) ‚Äì 1-D ndarray containing the sample points.

  • w (ndarray) ‚Äì 1-D ndarray containing the weights.

Notes

The function constructs the symmetric tridiagonal matrix and computes the eigenvalues and eigenvectors to obtain the quadrature points and weights.

The next steps ensure that zero is zero, and the points and weights are symmetric.

If the integration domain [a, b] is different from the default [-1, 1], the points and weights are transformed accordingly.

surfgeopy.remesh moduleÔÉÅ

remesh.pyÔÉÅ

Deal with re-triangulation of existing meshes.

surfgeopy.remesh.subdivide(vertices, faces, face_index=None, vertex_attributes=None, return_index=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Subdivide a mesh into smaller triangles. Note that if face_index is passed, only those faces will be subdivided and their neighbors won‚Äôt be modified, making the mesh no longer ‚Äúwatertight.‚Äù

Parameters:

  • vertices ((n, 3) float) ‚Äì Vertices in space

  • faces ((m, 3) int) ‚Äì Indices of vertices which make up triangular faces

  • face_index (array_like, optional) ‚Äì Indices of faces to subdivide. If None, all faces of the mesh will be subdivided.

  • vertex_attributes (dict, optional) ‚Äì Contains (n, d) attribute data

  • return_index (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, return index of original face for new faces

Returns:

  • new_vertices ((q, 3) float) ‚Äì Vertices in space

  • new_faces ((p, 3) int) ‚Äì Remeshed faces

  • index_dict (dict, optional) ‚Äì Only returned if return_index is True. {index of original face : index of new faces}.

surfgeopy.remesh.unique_ordered(data, return_index=False, return_inverse=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Returns the same as np.unique, but ordered as per the first occurrence of the unique value in data.

Parameters:

  • data (array-like) ‚Äì Input data

  • return_index (bool, optional) ‚Äì Return indices of unique values

  • return_inverse (bool, optional) ‚Äì Return the inverse of the unique array

Returns:

  • unique (array-like) ‚Äì The sorted unique values

  • index (array-like, optional) ‚Äì The indices of the unique values

  • inverse (array-like, optional) ‚Äì The indices to reconstruct the original data

surfgeopy.remesh.unique_rows(data, digits=None, keep_order=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Returns indices of unique rows. It will return the first occurrence of a row that is duplicated: [[1,2], [3,4], [1,2]] will return [0,1]

Parameters:

  • data ((n, m) array) ‚Äì Floating point data

  • digits (int or None, optional) ‚Äì Number of digits to consider for uniqueness

Returns:

  • unique ((j,) int) ‚Äì Index in data which is a unique row

  • inverse ((n,) int) ‚Äì Array to reconstruct original Example: data[unique][inverse] == data

surfgeopy.surf_integration moduleÔÉÅ

surfgeopy.surf_integration.compute_surf_quadrature(ls_function: Callable[[ndarray], float], ls_grad_func: Callable[[ndarray], ndarray], vertices: ndarray, faces: ndarray, interp_deg: int, lp_dgr: int, Refinement: int, fun_handle: Callable[[ndarray], float], deg_integration: int = 14, quadrature_rule: str = 'Pull_back_Gauss') → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray][source]ÔÉÅ

Compute quadrature points and weights on curved triangles.

Parameters:

  • ls_function ‚Äì Callable[[np.ndarray], float]: Zero-levelset function.

  • ls_grad_func ‚Äì Callable[[np.ndarray], np.ndarray]: Gradient of zero-levelset function.

  • vertices ‚Äì np.ndarray: Array of vertex coordinates.

  • faces ‚Äì np.ndarray: Array of face connectivity.

  • interp_deg ‚Äì int: Interpolation degree.

  • lp_dgr ‚Äì int: \(l_p\)-norm, which is used to define the polynomial degree.

  • Refinement ‚Äì int: Refinement level.

  • fun_handle ‚Äì Callable[[np.ndarray], float]: Function to be evaluated on each quadrature point.

  • deg_integration ‚Äì int: Degree of integration (default: 14).

  • quadrature_rule ‚Äì str: Quadrature rule type (‚ÄòGauss_Legendre‚Äô or ‚ÄòGauss_Simplex‚Äô).

Returns:

Quadrature points, weights, and offset array.

Return type:

Tuple[np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray]

surfgeopy.surf_integration.integration(ls_function: ~typing.Callable[[~numpy.ndarray], float], ls_grad_func: ~typing.Callable[[~numpy.ndarray], ~numpy.ndarray], mesh: str, interp_deg: int, lp_dgr: int, Refinement: int, fun_handle: ~typing.Callable[[~numpy.ndarray], float] = <function <lambda>>, deg_integration: int = -1, quadrature_rule: ~typing.Optional[str] = None) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Compute the integration of a function over curved triangles.

Parameters:

  • ls_function (Callable[[np.ndarray], float]) ‚Äì Zero-levelset function.

  • ls_grad_func (Callable[[np.ndarray], np.ndarray]) ‚Äì Gradient of the zero-levelset function.

  • mesh (str) ‚Äì The file path to the MAT file containing mesh data.

  • interp_deg (int) ‚Äì Interpolation degree.

  • lp_dgr (int) ‚Äì The l_p-norm used to define the polynomial degree.

  • Refinement (int) ‚Äì Refinement level.

  • fun_handle (Callable[[np.ndarray], float], optional) ‚Äì Function to be evaluated on each quadrature point. Defaults to a constant function.

  • deg_integration (int, optional) ‚Äì Degree of integration. Defaults to -1 (use default configuration).

  • quadrature_rule (Optional[str], optional) ‚Äì Quadrature rule type. Can be ‚ÄòGauss_Legendre‚Äô or ‚ÄòGauss_Simplex‚Äô. Defaults to None.

Returns:

Integration values for each curved triangle.

Return type:

np.ndarray

surfgeopy.surf_integration.quadrature_split_surf_tri(ls_function: Callable[[ndarray], float], ls_grad_func: Callable[[ndarray], ndarray], vertices: ndarray, faces: ndarray, interp_deg: int, lp_dgr: int, Refinement: int, fun_handle: Callable[[ndarray], float], deg_integration: int, quadrature_rule: str, pnts: ndarray, ws: ndarray, index: int) → int[source]ÔÉÅ

  • ls_grad_func ‚Äì Callable[[np.ndarray], np.ndarray]: Gradient of the zero-levelset function.

  • faces ‚Äì np.ndarray: Array of face connectivity.

  • interp_deg ‚Äì int: Interpolation degree.

  • lp_dgr ‚Äì int: \(l_p\)-norm, which is used to define the polynomial degree.

  • deg_integration ‚Äì int: Degree of integration.

  • quadrature_rule ‚Äì str: Quadrature rule type (‚ÄòGauss_Legendre‚Äô or ‚ÄòGauss_Simplex‚Äô).

  • pnts ‚Äì np.ndarray: Quadrature points array.

  • ws ‚Äì np.ndarray: Quadrature weights array.

  • index ‚Äì int: Current index in the arrays.

Returns:

surfgeopy.version moduleÔÉÅ

Module contentsÔÉÅ

This is the curved_integration package initialization file.

It imports all necessary submodules and defines the package‚Äôs public API.

surfgeopy.compute_surf_quadrature(ls_function: Callable[[ndarray], float], ls_grad_func: Callable[[ndarray], ndarray], vertices: ndarray, faces: ndarray, interp_deg: int, lp_dgr: int, Refinement: int, fun_handle: Callable[[ndarray], float], deg_integration: int = 14, quadrature_rule: str = 'Pull_back_Gauss') → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray][source]ÔÉÅ

Compute quadrature points and weights on curved triangles.

Parameters:

  • ls_function ‚Äì Callable[[np.ndarray], float]: Zero-levelset function.

  • ls_grad_func ‚Äì Callable[[np.ndarray], np.ndarray]: Gradient of zero-levelset function.

  • vertices ‚Äì np.ndarray: Array of vertex coordinates.

  • faces ‚Äì np.ndarray: Array of face connectivity.

  • interp_deg ‚Äì int: Interpolation degree.

  • lp_dgr ‚Äì int: \(l_p\)-norm, which is used to define the polynomial degree.

  • Refinement ‚Äì int: Refinement level.

  • fun_handle ‚Äì Callable[[np.ndarray], float]: Function to be evaluated on each quadrature point.

  • deg_integration ‚Äì int: Degree of integration (default: 14).

  • quadrature_rule ‚Äì str: Quadrature rule type (‚ÄòGauss_Legendre‚Äô or ‚ÄòGauss_Simplex‚Äô).

Returns:

Quadrature points, weights, and offset array.

Return type:

Tuple[np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray]

surfgeopy.integration(ls_function: ~typing.Callable[[~numpy.ndarray], float], ls_grad_func: ~typing.Callable[[~numpy.ndarray], ~numpy.ndarray], mesh: str, interp_deg: int, lp_dgr: int, Refinement: int, fun_handle: ~typing.Callable[[~numpy.ndarray], float] = <function <lambda>>, deg_integration: int = -1, quadrature_rule: ~typing.Optional[str] = None) → ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Compute the integration of a function over curved triangles.

Parameters:

  • ls_function (Callable[[np.ndarray], float]) ‚Äì Zero-levelset function.

  • ls_grad_func (Callable[[np.ndarray], np.ndarray]) ‚Äì Gradient of the zero-levelset function.

  • mesh (str) ‚Äì The file path to the MAT file containing mesh data.

  • interp_deg (int) ‚Äì Interpolation degree.

  • lp_dgr (int) ‚Äì The l_p-norm used to define the polynomial degree.

  • Refinement (int) ‚Äì Refinement level.

  • fun_handle (Callable[[np.ndarray], float], optional) ‚Äì Function to be evaluated on each quadrature point. Defaults to a constant function.

  • deg_integration (int, optional) ‚Äì Degree of integration. Defaults to -1 (use default configuration).

  • quadrature_rule (Optional[str], optional) ‚Äì Quadrature rule type. Can be ‚ÄòGauss_Legendre‚Äô or ‚ÄòGauss_Simplex‚Äô. Defaults to None.

Returns:

Integration values for each curved triangle.

Return type:

np.ndarray

Compute the maximum edge length of a triangle defined by its vertices.

Parameters:

xs (numpy.ndarray) ‚Äì Array of shape (3, N) representing N triangles, where each row contains the coordinates of the vertices of a triangle in 3D space.

Returns:

Maximum edge length among all the triangles.

Return type:

float

surfgeopy.q_gauss_legendre(n, Domain=array([- 1, 1]))[source]ÔÉÅ

Generate quadrature weights and nodes for Gauss-Legendre quadrature rule.

An n-point Gauss-Legendre quadrature rule is of degree 2n-1; that is, it integrates all polynomials up to degree 2n-1 exactly.

Parameters:

  • n (int) ‚Äì Number of sample points and weights. It must be >= 1.

  • Domain (ndarray, optional) ‚Äì Refers to the domain of integration [a, b]. The default domain is the bi-unit interval [-1, 1].

Returns:

  • x (ndarray) ‚Äì 1-D ndarray containing the sample points.

  • w (ndarray) ‚Äì 1-D ndarray containing the weights.

Notes

The function constructs the symmetric tridiagonal matrix and computes the eigenvalues and eigenvectors to obtain the quadrature points and weights.

The next steps ensure that zero is zero, and the points and weights are symmetric.

If the integration domain [a, b] is different from the default [-1, 1], the points and weights are transformed accordingly.

surfgeopy.quadrature_split_surf_tri(ls_function: Callable[[ndarray], float], ls_grad_func: Callable[[ndarray], ndarray], vertices: ndarray, faces: ndarray, interp_deg: int, lp_dgr: int, Refinement: int, fun_handle: Callable[[ndarray], float], deg_integration: int, quadrature_rule: str, pnts: ndarray, ws: ndarray, index: int) → int[source]ÔÉÅ

For a mixed mesh, find the cell integration of the test function f.

Parameters:

  • ls_function ‚Äì Callable[[np.ndarray], float]: Zero-levelset function.

  • ls_grad_func ‚Äì Callable[[np.ndarray], np.ndarray]: Gradient of the zero-levelset function.

  • vertices ‚Äì np.ndarray: Array of vertex coordinates.

  • faces ‚Äì np.ndarray: Array of face connectivity.

  • interp_deg ‚Äì int: Interpolation degree.

  • lp_dgr ‚Äì int: \(l_p\)-norm, which is used to define the polynomial degree.

  • deg_integration ‚Äì int: Degree of integration.

  • quadrature_rule ‚Äì str: Quadrature rule type (‚ÄòGauss_Legendre‚Äô or ‚ÄòGauss_Simplex‚Äô).

  • pnts ‚Äì np.ndarray: Quadrature points array.

  • ws ‚Äì np.ndarray: Quadrature weights array.

  • index ‚Äì int: Current index in the arrays.

Returns:

Updated index value.

Return type:

int

surfgeopy.quadrule_on_simplex(deg)[source]ÔÉÅ
Parameters:

  • deg (Algebraic degree of precision of the rule.) ‚Äì Algebraic degree of precision of the rule.

  • 0] (CUBATURE RULE ON THE SIMPLEX [0 0; 0 1; 1) ‚Äì

  • Legend ‚Äì

  • #DEG (algebraic degree of precision.) ‚Äì

  • #CARD (cardinality of the pointset.) ‚Äì

  • #W- (negative weights.) ‚Äì

surfgeopy.subdivide(vertices, faces, face_index=None, vertex_attributes=None, return_index=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Subdivide a mesh into smaller triangles. Note that if face_index is passed, only those faces will be subdivided and their neighbors won‚Äôt be modified, making the mesh no longer ‚Äúwatertight.‚Äù

Parameters:

  • vertices ((n, 3) float) ‚Äì Vertices in space

  • faces ((m, 3) int) ‚Äì Indices of vertices which make up triangular faces

  • face_index (array_like, optional) ‚Äì Indices of faces to subdivide. If None, all faces of the mesh will be subdivided.

  • vertex_attributes (dict, optional) ‚Äì Contains (n, d) attribute data

  • return_index (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, return index of original face for new faces

Returns:

  • new_vertices ((q, 3) float) ‚Äì Vertices in space

  • new_faces ((p, 3) int) ‚Äì Remeshed faces

  • index_dict (dict, optional) ‚Äì Only returned if return_index is True. {index of original face : index of new faces}.

surfgeopy.unique_ordered(data, return_index=False, return_inverse=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Returns the same as np.unique, but ordered as per the first occurrence of the unique value in data.

Parameters:

  • data (array-like) ‚Äì Input data

  • return_index (bool, optional) ‚Äì Return indices of unique values

  • return_inverse (bool, optional) ‚Äì Return the inverse of the unique array

Returns:

  • unique (array-like) ‚Äì The sorted unique values

  • index (array-like, optional) ‚Äì The indices of the unique values

  • inverse (array-like, optional) ‚Äì The indices to reconstruct the original data

surfgeopy.unique_rows(data, digits=None, keep_order=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Returns indices of unique rows. It will return the first occurrence of a row that is duplicated: [[1,2], [3,4], [1,2]] will return [0,1]

Parameters:

  • data ((n, m) array) ‚Äì Floating point data

  • digits (int or None, optional) ‚Äì Number of digits to consider for uniqueness

Returns:

  • unique ((j,) int) ‚Äì Index in data which is a unique row

  • inverse ((n,) int) ‚Äì Array to reconstruct original Example: data[unique][inverse] == data
